Expectation1: Complete any assignments or tasks given by the mentor.
Situation1: The mentor assigned a code sample to be finished before the next meeting in three days.
Expectation2: Provide guidance to clients regarding machine usage
Situation2: An operator keeps tweaking settings incorrectly, causing noticeable material waste.
Story: I stared at the code sample my mentor had sent, the lines blurring together as I tried to focus. The assignment was due in three days, and I knew she expected me to not only finish it but also understand every part. My phone buzzed again—another message from the factory floor. The operator was having trouble with the new press, and from the photos, I could see the material waste piling up. I was supposed to guide him, make sure he learned the right settings, but every time I explained, he’d try something different and make it worse. My mentor’s words echoed in my mind: “Take initiative, show me you can handle complex tasks.” But the operator needed me now, and if I didn’t help, the waste would keep growing. I felt pulled in two directions—one part of me desperate to prove myself as a mentee, the other knowing I couldn’t ignore the responsibility of guiding the operator. My hands hovered over the keyboard, torn between debugging my code and composing another message to the floor, my chest tight with the weight of both expectations.
